messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
> Mike wrote:
>
> > Where I am
> > struggling is how to get my Tests to:
> >
> > - Grab a batch, and then cycle through the objects related to that
> > batch, running every test on each object
>
> This sounds like a Parameterized Test Case: you want to execute the
same
> test logic for many rows of data. I would search the archives of
this
> group for "Parameterized Test Case".

It is similar I think. Perhaps what I should do is mention more
about how I am allowed to access the data because of the way the
platform hides the actual implentation.

Unfortunately, it's not as easy as just grabbing rows. I get an
object which represents a file batch. Then I can walk through that
batch to grab each record using a singleton on the batch object.
Each record is what I ultimately want to test upon. The only way to
get to a record is through a batch.

Ideally, I want to be able to run these tests on any batch which are
referenced by an ID set at load time. Ultimately, when a client
changes something, I want to be sure they didn't break the rules that
were used to extract the data.

The way I envision it, is you grab a batch, then iterate through the
batch getting each record object. Once you've gotten the object, you
then run your series of unit tests on that object. YOu can check
that data is still there, to verifying that the JSP page that
accesses this object contains everything that it is supposed to. The
one thing to note is that the record is not a row, it's a BLOB which
can be accessed through accessor objects to get the data.

This is what I meant by cascading down. My input is just the batch
ID, and I need to use that to get what I really want to test which
are the records associated with that batch.

What I'm seeing in your post, is that I may be a bit too
ambitious/backwards. :) Perhaps I need to send the batch into the
test and then iterate through each record rather than iterate through
each record and pass it into each test.

I was asking about where I might place the code to open and close the
DB connection so I don't lose the connection while I'm trying to
ulimately get to the record. I don't want to open and close the
connection for each record. :)

You are quite correct that the complications come from the
application...I have written some basic jUnit tests over the past
month.

I just want to fit within the jUnit framework as much as possible.
Another collegue wrote some code to test the web end, which used
jUnit and httpUnit, but he proceeded to overload every assert method
and write one giant testThis method within which you called methods
to test. Seemed to really defeat the purpose of testing with the
jUnit framework, and sent me on this mission to find a better way.

I don't know if this makes any more sence..but hopefully it helps to
clarify.
